greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: a(n) is the period of A000930 modulo n.
link: Joerg Arndt, Table of n, a(n) for n = 1..1000
H. T. Engstrom, On sequences defined by linear recurrence relations, Trans. Am. Math. Soc. 33 (1) (1931) 210-218.
K. Kirthi, Narayana Sequences for Cryptographic Applications, arXiv preprint arXiv:1509.05745 [math.NT], 2015.
M. B. Nathanson, Linear recurrences and uniform distribution, Proc. Amer. Math. Soc. 48 (1975), 289-291.
D. D. Wall, Fibonacci series modulo m, Amer. Math. Monthly, 67 (1960), 525-532.
formula: Let the prime factorization of n be p1^e1*...*pk^ek. Then a(n) = lcm(a(p1^e1), ..., a(pk^ek)) [Engstrom]. - _N. J. A. Sloane_, Feb 18 2017
mathematica: a[n_] := Module[{p0=0, len=minlen}, While[p0 = Mod[LinearRecurrence[{1, 0, 1}, {1, 1, 1}, len], n] // per; p0<=1 && len<=maxlen, len = 2 len]; p0];
Table[an = a[n]; Print["a(", n, ") = ", an]; an, {n, 1, 100}] (* _Jean-François Alcover_, Jul 21 2018 *)
program: per(n, S, R) = {  \\ S[]: leading terms, R[]: recurrence
if ( r != #S , error("Mismatch in length of S[] and R[]") );
my( t = sum(i=1, r, R[i] * T[r+1-i] ) );  \\ next term
xref: Cf. A000930, A271901 (periods mod primes), A001175 (periods of A000045 modulo n).
results.author: _Joerg Arndt_, Apr 17 2016
